brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine if the quality of life in children and adolescents
      diagnosed with chronic functional constipation improves after educational activity in focus
      group composed by these patients' mothers.

clinical_study.brief_title: Quality of Life in Children and Adolescents With Chronic Functional Constipation: Educational Action Effects

detailed_description.textblock:
The present research will be conducted on the specific constipation clinic in Hospital das
      Clínicas at Universidade Federal de Pernambuco.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Children (6 to 9 years-old) and adolescents

          -  Diagnostic of chronic functional constipation

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients using calcium and/or heme

          -  Patients with organic diseases that causes constipation

clinical_study.official_title: Quality of Life in Children and Adolescents With Chronic Functional Constipation: Educational Action Effects

primary_outcome.description: The quality of life outcomes will be assessed by using the Generic Core Questionnaires (Standard form) of Measurement Model for the Pediatric Quality of Life InventoryTM version (PedsQL) 4.0 Generic Core Scales (VARNI et al., 2001) was translated and validated in Brazil by Klatchoian et al. (2008).
primary_outcome.measure: The improvement in the quality of life on participants after the intervention

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: The clinical parameters were assessed according to a specific questionnaire used on patient assistance at clinical hospital at UFPE. This questionnaire will be applied before and after the intervention.
secondary_outcome.measure: The improvement in clinical parameters of chronic functional constipation

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Supportive Care
